title: Bulgaria adopts the euro as official currency despite concerns it’s economically damaging
description: Bulgaria has adopted the euro as its official currency, becoming the 21st country to join the eurozone.  The Southeast European country has been a member of the European Union since 2007.   Bulgaria formally met the entry requirements for the eurozone monetary area in January 2025.   Concerns have been raised within Bulgaria that adopting the euro could be economically damaging.

title: Four people have drowned and two people are missing after New Year's Celebrations
description: Authorities say it has been a tough 24 hours after four people have drowned and two people, including a teenager, are missing.  On January 1, the body of a 25-year-old woman was recovered at 5 am at Maroubra Beach, and an hour later, a man was swept away in rough surf at Coogee Beach.   Later that afternoon, a 45-year-old woman drowned in Camden Haven, followed by another drowning at Avoca Beach at around 6:45 pm.   A boat capsized in Palm Beach on December 31, leaving one man dead, 14 a 14-year-old boy missing and a third person injured.  Surf Life Saving New South Wales is warning people to avoid going into the water if the beach is closed.

title: Snorkeller missing after entering the water at Ledge Point Beach near Perth
description: A snorkeller has been confirmed missing after entering the water at Ledge Point Beach near Perth.  WA police received reports of a missing man around 3 pm on December 31.    The search will resume in the city's north on January 2.

title: Minnesota daycare scam risks families losing childcare during a federal freeze
description: Families in Minnesota are in danger of losing childcare after the federal government announced a freeze on childcare payments.   The Trump administration announced it’s holding back funding for daycares in Minnesota because of allegations of widespread fraud made in a viral video from YouTube influencer Nick Shirley.  Federal officials have also said all states will have to change how they submit receipts for childcare reimbursement.

title: Australian cricketer Usman Khawaja announces his retirement
description: Australian cricketer Usman Khawaja announces his retirement from all international cricket after the SCG test match.  “I thought one day I’m going to be a test cricketer and one day I can drive whatever I want,” Mr Khawaja said.  “I’m here to announce today that I’ll be retiring from all international cricket.  “No career belongs to one person; I obviously had a lot of help.  “I’ve been incredibly lucky with the people I’ve gotten to be around.  “As I walk off for the last time, I do so with peace.”

title: ‘Tragic 48 hours’: Lifeguards plea for Australians to be responsible in the surf
description: Surf Life Saving NSW Public Safety General Manager Brent Manieri discusses the tragic 48 hours which have claimed multiple lives due to drownings.  “Since Christmas, our lifesavers and lifeguards have undertaken over 100 rescues,” Mr Manieri told Sky News Australia.  “People need to understand what their skill level is in the water.  “We’re really pleading with the community to work with us.”

title: China shows how Robot wolves could be used to attack Taiwan
description: Recent footage aired on state TV reveals how China’s robot wolves could be used to attack Taiwan.  The robots are used to carry ammunition and clear simulated mines.  Taiwan analysts have downplayed the robots' threat to the island due to the machines' struggle in battle environments and susceptibility to signal jammers.

title: ‘Less than a 50 per cent chance of peace’: Ukraine’s peace prospects dwindling
description: Former home affairs secretary Mike Pezzullo explains what peace prospects Ukraine could have in the future.  “I just fear that Putin’s not going to back off from his outrageous demands for territory,” Mr Pezzullo told Sky News Australia.  “I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but I think this is intractable.  “My call at the moment would be that there’s a less than 50 per cent chance of getting some kind of sustainable or enduring peace.”

title: Iran's ‘buying for time’ as protests sweep the country
description: Naval Warfare Senior Research Fellow Brent Sadler states Iran is “buying for time” to outlast US President Donald Trump’s administration and have a more “amenable” leader in Washington, DC.  “The Iranian regime is buying for time … they certainly don't want to give up their ballistic missile programs, nor their nuclear weapons development program,” Mr Sadler told Sky News Australia.  “Right now, the regime is facing some severe protests across the country that appear to be spreading.  I think they’re trying to find some relief from the outside pressures as they turn inside.”

title: Trump’s war on ‘narco cartels’ continues as US strikes more alleged drug boats
description: Naval Warfare Senior Research Fellow Brent Sadler comments on the ongoing debate on “ethics” and the “legality” of US military strikes on alleged drug boats.  “For many years, there's been a war against these narco cartels,” Mr Sadler told Sky News Australia.  “It's largely centred on legal mechanisms, and there just isn't the capacity, and it hasn't been effective to curtail or to slow the infusions of these poisons into the US.”

title: China launches ‘sixth iteration’ of live-firing drills on Taiwan
description: Naval Warfare Senior Research Fellow Brent Sadler says China has carried out their “sixth iteration” of live-firing drills over Taiwan since 2022.  Mr Sadler told Sky News Australia, in “Justice Mission 2025,” there were 130 aircrafts, as well as a live-fire demonstration of a new “anti-ship ballistic missile”.  “The mainland Chinese have used this as a way to further refine and practice what would be a large-scale joint operation.”

title: ‘Give people satisfaction’: Calls for a Royal Commission continue to grow louder
description: Former home affairs secretary Mike Pezzullo pushes for a Royal Commission.  “It’s such a shocking event, so many innocent people killed,” Mr Pezzullo told Sky News Australia.  “I think it’s just so dramatically traumatising that it’s just created this groundswell from outside of politics.  “I think the reason why we need a Royal Commission is to give people satisfaction that it truly has been looked at independently of government and at arm’s length.”

title: ‘Really concerned about terrorist attacks’: Middle East tensions could impact the world
description: Former home affairs secretary Mike Pezzullo expresses his concerns about how wars in the Middle East could impact terrorism all around the world.   “I’m really concerned about spinoff terrorist inspired or terrorist directed attacks,” Mr Pezzullo told Sky News Australia.  “Follow on terrorist attacks all around the world, I’d be keeping an eye on that too.”

title: ‘We’re not terrorists in waiting’: Firearm owners outraged over new gun laws
description: New South Wales Independent MP Philip Donato says the gun law reforms were “rushed” as the government turned its focus onto “law-abiding firearm owners”.  “The way it was bundled up in a cognate bill with terrorist laws was also a bit of a slap in the face,” Mr Sadler told Sky News Australia.  “We’re not terrorists in waiting.”

title: ‘Gutted’: China’s beef import quota to impact regional communities
description: ​Nationals Leader David Littleproud says China’s strict quotas on Australia’s beef exports will particularly impact “regional communities”.  “We’re gutted, I mean, this is a billion dollars potentially that will come out of the wallets of Australian farmers,” Mr Littleproud told Sky News Australia.  “This is really the impact of significant imports from South America, and it's South America that should be singled out, not Australia.  “We're less than 10 per cent of the actual total beef imports into China.”
